Independent Auditor’s Report
To the Participants and Employee Benefit Committee
L3Harris Technologies Consolidated Pension Plan
Melbourne, Florida
Opinion
We have audited the financial statements of L3Harris Technologies Consolidated Pension Plan (the Plan), an
employee benefit plan subject to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), which comprise
the statements of net assets available for benefits as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, and the related statements
of changes in net assets available for benefits for the years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023, and the related
notes to the financial statements.
In our opinion, the accompanying financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, information regarding
the net assets available for benefits of the Plan as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, and the changes in its net assets
available for benefits for the years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023, in accordance with accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States of America (US GAAP).
Basis for Opinion
We conducted our audits in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of America
(US GAAS). Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the Auditor’s Responsibilities for the
Audit of the Financial Statements section of our report. We are required to be independent of the Plan and to meet
our other ethical responsibilities, in accordance with the relevant ethical requirements relating to our audits. We
believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit
opinion.
Emphasis of Matter
As discussed in Note 10 to the financial statements, the L3Harris Combat Propulsion Systems Pension Plan, the
Cooperative Pension Income Plan, the L3Harris Ocean Systems Pension Plan For Hourly Employees, and the
L3Harris Pension Plan for Employees at the Pacific Missile Range Facility merged into the Plan, effective as of
December 31, 2024. Our opinion is not modified with respect to that matter.
Responsibilities of Management for the Financial Statements
Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the financial statements in accordance with
US GAAP, and for the design, implementation, and maintenance of internal control relevant to the preparation and
fair presentation of financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.
In preparing the financial statements, management is required to evaluate whether there are conditions or events,
considered in the aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the Plan’s ability to continue as a going concern for
one year after the date that the financial statements are issued or are available to be issued.
Management is also responsible for maintaining a current plan instrument, including all plan amendments,
administering the Plan, and determining that the Plan’s transactions that are presented and disclosed in the financial
statements are in conformity with the Plan’s provisions, including maintaining sufficient records with respect to each
of the participants, to determine the benefits due or which may become due to such participants.
Weaver and Tidwell, L.L.P.
CPAs AND ADVISORS | WEAVER.COM

The Participants and Employee Benefit Committee
L3Harris Technologies Consolidated Pension Plan
Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements
Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a whole are free from
material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor’s report that includes our opinion.
Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance but is not absolute assurance and therefore is not a guarantee
that an audit conducted in accordance with US GAAS will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. The
risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as
fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control.
Misstatements are considered material if there is a substantial likelihood that, individually or in the aggregate, they
would influence the judgement made by a reasonable user based on the financial statements.
In performing an audit in accordance with US GAAS, we:
 Exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit.
 Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, whether due to fraud or
error, and design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks. Such procedures include
examining, on a test basis, evidence regarding the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
 Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that
are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness
of the Plan’s internal control. Accordingly, no such opinion is expressed.
 Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of significant accounting
estimates made by management, as well as evaluate the overall presentation of the financial statements.
 Conclude whether, in our judgment, there are conditions or events, considered in the aggregate, that raise
substantial doubt about the Plan’s ability to continue as a going concern for a reasonable period of time.
We are required to communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters, the planned
scope and timing of the audit, significant audit findings, and certain internal control-related matters that we
identified during the audit.

Note 1. Description of the Plan
The following description of the L3Harris Technologies Consolidated Pension Plan (the Plan) provides only general
information. Participants should refer to the Plan document for a more complete description of the Plan’s provisions,
which is available from Plan management.
General
The Plan was established effective May 1, 1997, in connection with the acquisition of certain entities, including
the L3 Aviation Products, Inc. division from Lockheed Martin Corporation (Lockheed Martin). On May 1, 1997, certain
participants in the Lockheed Martin Fairchild Corporation Retirement Plan (the Prior Plan) became participants in
the Plan. Lockheed Martin transferred the assets under the Prior Plan attributable to the accrued benefits of its
participants to the Plan. On June 29, 2019, L3 Technologies, Inc. (L3) completed its merger with Harris Corporation
(Harris) to create L3Harris Technologies, Inc. (the Company) (the Plan Sponsor). Effective January 1, 2023, the plan
was renamed to be the L3Harris Technologies Consolidated Pension Plan. The Plan is a defined benefit plan covering
employees at certain locations of the Company. The Plan funds are held in the L3Harris Pension Master Trust. See
Note 3 for further information regarding the Master Trust. The Plan is subject to the provisions of the Employee
Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), as amended.
Effective December 31, 2023, the Aerojet Rocketdyne (GenCorp) Consolidated Pension Plan merged into the plan.
See Notes 10 and 11 for additional information.
Effective December 31, 2024, the L3Harris Combat Propulsion Systems Pension Plan, the Cooperative Pension
Income Plan, the L3Harris Ocean Systems Pension Plan for Hourly Employees, and the L3Harris Pension Plan for
Employees at the Pacific Missile Range Facility merged into the plan. See Notes 10 and 11 for additional information.
Master Trust
The Northern Trust Company (the Trustee or Northern Trust) serves as trustee of the Plan and administers the Plan’s
investment assets. The Plan’s assets consist of an undivided interest in an investment account of the L3Harris Pension
Master Trust, EIN 36-6668234, a master trust established by the Company and administered by the Trustee. The
Master Trust includes the combined assets of the Plan, as well as several other employee benefit plans of the
Company. Although assets of the Plan are commingled in the Master Trust, the Trustee maintains supporting records
for the purpose of allocating the net gain of the investment account to the participating plans. The net investment
income of the investment assets is allocated by the Trustee to each participating plan based on the relationship of
the interest of each plan to the total of the interests of the participating plans. A schedule of the Master Trust assets
has been filed with the U.S. Department of Labor and includes the Plan’s proportionate share of such assets at
December 31, 2024 and 2023.
Eligibility
Eligibility requirements vary pursuant to the terms of each of the component plans. Generally, employees must be
hired by one of the business units associated with one of the component plans, and the hire date must be before
the component plan is closed to new entrants. Some component plans may require the employees to be represented
by a specific union. Each component plan requires a minimum employment period for participation. This period
ranges from immediate participants to requiring 1 year of service.
5

L3Harris Technologies Consolidated Pension Plan
Notes to Financial Statements
(In Thousands)
Funding Policy
Contributions to provide benefits under the Plan are made by the Company and component plans may require
employee contributions based on a percentage of their eligible compensation. The Company’s funding policy is to
make cash contributions to the Plan in amounts as determined by the Plan’s independent actuary. During 2024
and 2023, the Company made contributions of $24,352 and $0, respectively. The Company met the minimum
funding requirements of ERISA for the years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023.
Employees’ accumulated contributions with interest as of January 1, 2024 and 2023 were $2,150 and $2,096
respectively. Employee contributions were credited interest at a rate of 5.25% and 4.62% as of January 1, 2024
and 2023.
Pension Benefits
Participants typically become eligible for a monthly benefit at age 65. Some component plans also require up
to 5 years of vesting service to be eligible for the benefit. Depending on the component plan, benefits are calculated
in various ways, commonly by applying a percentage of the final average pay multiplied by the number of service
years, a percentage of salary during the periods when service years were accumulated, or by multiplying the service
years by a pension rate. The rates and percentages may vary based on the applicable component plan.
Generally, participants are eligible to receive early retirement benefits between the ages of 50 and 65 after earning
sufficient service credits, which range from 5 to 20 years, depending on the component plan and the type of early
retirement. Early retirement benefits are computed in a manner similar to normal retirement at age 65, except that
benefits are reduced by early retirement factors for each month that the early retirement date precedes the normal
retirement date. Some component plans offer unreduced early retirement upon meeting certain age and service
requirements.
Death Benefits and Disability Benefits
Certain component plans provide death and disability benefits. Generally, for those plans, a married covered
employee who is a vested participant is automatically covered by the vested spouse’s benefit that provides for
spousal survivorship benefits in the event of the employee’s death prior to becoming eligible for early or normal
retirement benefits. Also, a participant who is eligible for early or normal retirement is automatically covered by a
pre-retirement survivor’s benefit that provides for survivorship benefits payable to the participant’s named
beneficiary in the event of the participant’s death prior to the benefit commencement date.
Several of the component plans offer disability benefits for employees who become totally and permanently
disabled. To be eligible, participants usually are required to earn a certain amount of years of service, which range
between 5 to 15 years depending on the component plan; age requirements may also apply. The benefit amount is
computed as it would be for normal retirement based on the employee’s years of service as of the date of disability.
6

L3Harris Technologies Consolidated Pension Plan
Notes to Financial Statements
(In Thousands)
401(h) Account
The Plan includes a medical benefit (health and welfare) component in addition to normal retirement benefits to
fund a portion of the postretirement obligations for retirees and their beneficiaries in accordance with Section 401(h)
of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC or the Code). A separate account has been established and maintained in the
Plan for the net assets related to the health and welfare component (401(h) Account). In accordance with
Section 401(h) of the Code, the Plan’s investments in the 401(h) Account may not be used for, or diverted to, any
purpose other than providing health and welfare benefits to retirees and participants. Any assets transferred to
the 401(h) Account from the Plan in a qualified transfer of excess pension plan assets (and any income allocable
thereto) that are not used during the plan year must be transferred out of the account to the Plan. The related
obligations for health and welfare benefits are not included in the Plan’s actuarial present value of accumulated plan
benefits but are reflected as obligations in the financial statements of L3Harris Retiree Health and Welfare Plan, the
Company’s health and welfare benefit plan. Plan participants do not contribute to the 401(h) Account. Employer
contributions or qualified transfers to the 401(h) Account are determined annually at the discretion of the Plan
Sponsor.
In December 2012, the 401(h) Account was segregated into two 401(h) subaccounts. One for the funding designated
for retiree medical expenses and the other for retiree prescription drug expenses. The Company began drawing
down funds from the 401(h) Account to pay for qualified retiree medical and prescription costs in December 2012
and anticipates continuing drawing funds from the 401(h) Account going forward.
Note 2. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Basis of Accounting
The accompanying financial statements are prepared using the accrual basis of accounting.
Use of Estimates
The preparation of financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the
United States of America (US GAAP) requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the
reported amounts of assets, liabilities, and changes therein; and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities and
the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits at the date of the financial statements, and changes therein.
Actual results could differ from those estimates.
Investment Valuation and Income Recognition
The Plan’s interest in the Master Trust is presented at fair value, which has been determined based on the fair value
of the underlying investments of the Master Trust. Fair value of a financial instrument is the amount that would be
received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the
measurement date. See Note 6 for discussion of fair value measurements.
Purchases and sales of securities are recorded on a trade-date basis. Interest income is recorded on the accrual
basis. Dividends are recorded on the ex-dividend date. Net appreciation (depreciation) includes the Plan’s gains and
losses on investments bought and sold as well as held during the year.
Payment of Benefits
Benefits are recorded upon distribution.

Administrative Expenses
Administrative expenses of the Plan are paid by the Master Trust on behalf of the Plan, as provided in the plan
document and the Master Trust agreement. Expenses that are paid directly by the Company are excluded from these
financial statements. Certain expenses incurred in connection with the general administration of the Plan that are
paid by the Plan are recorded as deductions in the accompanying statement of changes in net assets available for
benefits. Administrative expenses generally consist of consulting fees, auditing fees, recordkeeping fees, and
insurance expense. In addition, certain investment related expenses are included in Plan’s interest in the Master
Trust investment income presented in the accompanying statement of changes in net assets available for benefits.

Note 4. Accumulated Plan Benefits
Accumulated plan benefits are those future periodic payments, including lump-sum distributions that are
attributable under the Plan’s provisions to the services employees have rendered. Accumulated plan benefits include
benefits expected to be paid to (a) retired or terminated employees or their beneficiaries, (b) beneficiaries of
employees who have died, and (c) present employees or their beneficiaries. Benefits under the Plan are accumulated
based on employees’ compensation during each year of credited service. The accumulated plan benefits for active
employees will equal the accumulation, with interest, of the annual benefit accruals as of the benefit information
date. Benefits payable under all circumstances (retirement, death, disability, and termination of employment) are
included, to the extent they are deemed attributable to employee service rendered prior to the valuation date.
Benefits to be provided via annuity contracts excluded from plan assets are excluded from accumulated plan
benefits.
The actuarial present value of the accumulated plan benefits is determined by the Plan’s independent actuary and
is the amount that results from applying actuarial assumptions to adjust the accumulated plan benefits to reflect
the time value of money (through discounts for interest) and probability of payment (by means of decrements such
as for death, disability, withdrawal, or retirement) between the valuation date and the expected date of payment.

Note 5. Plan Termination
While the Company has not expressed any intent to do so, it is free to discontinue its contributions at any time and
to terminate the Plan, subject to the provisions set forth in ERISA.
10

L3Harris Technologies Consolidated Pension Plan
Notes to Financial Statements
(In Thousands)
In the event the Plan terminates, the net assets of the Plan will be allocated as prescribed by ERISA and its related
regulations, generally to provide the following benefits in the order indicated:
a. Benefits attributable to employee contributions, taking into account those paid out before termination.
b. Benefits attributable to participants who have retired at least three years before the termination date of the
Plan or those participants who were eligible to retire and receive pension benefits at least three years before,
but who did not elect to retire at that time.
c. Benefits commencing at retirement age to participants who are eligible to receive guaranteed benefits
under ERISA.
d. All vested and non-vested benefits.
Certain benefits under the Plan are insured by the PBGC if the Plan terminates. Generally, the PBGC guarantees most
vested normal age retirement benefits, early retirement benefits, and certain disability and survivors’ pensions.
However, the PBGC does not guarantee all types of benefits under the Plan and the amount of benefit protection is
subject to certain limitations. Vested benefits under the Plan are guaranteed at the level in effect on the date of the
Plan’s termination.
Whether participants receive all benefits to which they are entitled under the terms of the Plan should the Plan
terminate at some future time will depend on the sufficiency, at that time, of the Plan’s net assets to provide for
accumulated benefit obligations and may also depend on the financial condition of the plan sponsor and the level
of benefits guaranteed by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, up to specified limits.
Note 6. Fair Value Measurements
Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) Accounting Standards Codification (ASC) 820, Fair Value
Measurement, provides the framework for measuring fair value. That framework provides a fair value hierarchy that
prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value. The hierarchy gives the highest priority to
unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1) and the lowest priority to
unobservable inputs (Level 3). The three levels of the fair value hierarchy under FASB ASC 820 are described as
follows:
Level 1 Inputs to the valuation methodology are unadjusted quoted prices for identical assets or
liabilities in active markets that the Plan has the ability to access.
Level 2 Inputs to the valuation methodology include:
 Quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities in active markets;
 Quoted prices for identical or similar assets or liabilities in inactive markets;
 Inputs other than quoted prices that are observable for the asset or liability; and
 Inputs that are derived principally from or corroborated by observable market data
by correlation or other means.
If the asset or liability has a specified (contractual) term, the Level 2 input must be observable for
substantially the full term of the asset or liability.
Level 3 Inputs to the valuation methodology are unobservable and significant to the fair value
measurement.
11

L3Harris Technologies Consolidated Pension Plan
Notes to Financial Statements
(In Thousands)
The asset or liability’s fair value measurement level within the fair value hierarchy is based on the lowest level of any
input that is significant to the fair value measurement. Valuation techniques used need to maximize the use of
observable inputs and minimize the use of unobservable inputs.
Following is a description of the valuation methodologies used for assets measured at fair value. There have been
no changes in the methodologies used at December 31, 2024 and 2023.
Domestic and international equity: Domestic and international equity includes common and preferred stocks,
domestic listed and foreign listed equity securities, unit trust equities, stapled securities, open-ended and
closed-ended mutual funds, exchange-traded funds (registered investment companies), and these are generally
valued at the closing price reported on the major market on which the individual securities are traded at the
measurement date.
REITs: Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs) consist of securities that trade on the major exchanges and invest
directly in real estate, either through properties or mortgages.
Fixed income investments: Fixed income investments include U.S. government securities, corporate bonds,
corporate convertible bonds, asset-backed securities, bank loans, government mortgage backed securities,
non-government backed collateralized mortgage obligations and municipal obligations, which are generally valued
using pricing models that use verifiable, observable market data such as interest rates, benchmark yield, and bids
provided by brokers or dealers, or quoted prices of securities with similar characteristics.
Short-term investments: Short-term investments are primarily comprised of short-term money market funds, which
invest primarily in short-term, high quality money market securities such as government obligations, commercial
paper, time deposits and certificates of deposit which are valued at cost, which approximate fair value, or valued at
quoted market prices of identical instruments.
Partnerships/joint ventures: Limited partnership funds include buy-out (developing companies), mezzanine
(funds providing mezzanine loans to companies), venture capital (start-up companies), distressed asset
(distressed companies undergoing bankruptcies, etc.), commodities (businesses in commodity related sectors), real
estate (residential, commercial, and industrial real estate), international equity and venture capital, and are typically
limited partnership investment structures and/or joint ventures. Limited partnership valuations are based on the
valuation of the underlying investments, which include inputs such as cost, operating results, discounted future cash
flows and market-based comparable data. Net asset value (NAV) is used as a practical expedient to estimate fair
value.
Hedge funds: Hedge funds include equity long/short, event driven, multi-strategy, real estate and fund of funds,
and are typically limited partnership investment structures. Limited partnership interests in hedge funds are primarily
valued using a market approach based on net asset value (NAV) calculated by the funds and are not publicly
available. NAV is used as a practical expedient to estimate fair value.
Common collective trusts: Common collective trusts (CCTs) are valued at NAV and are arrangements in which the
funds of individual trusts are pooled to avail themselves of professional investment management and achieve
greater diversification of investment, stability of income, or other investment objectives. CCTs are reported at
NAV, as of the measurement date. NAV is used as a practical expedient to estimate fair value.

Note 7. Risks and Uncertainties
The Plan, through the Master Trust, invests in various investment securities that are exposed to various risks such as
interest rates, market and credit risks. Market values of investments may decline for a number of reasons, including
changes in prevailing market and interest rates, increases in defaults and credit rating downgrades. Market risks
include global events, which could impact the value of investment securities, such as a pandemic or international
conflict. Due to the level of risk associated with certain investment securities, it is at least reasonably possible that
changes in the values of investment securities will occur in the near term and that some changes could materially
affect the amounts reported in the statement of net assets available for benefits.
Plan contributions are determined and the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits are reported based
on certain assumptions pertaining to interest rates, inflation rates, and employee demographics, all of which are
subject to change. Due to uncertainties inherent in the estimations and assumptions process, it is at least reasonably
possible that changes in these estimates and assumptions in the near term would be material to the financial
statements.
Note 8. Tax Status
The Plan obtained its latest determination letter on September 16, 2025, in which the Internal Revenue Service (IRS)
stated that the Plan and related trust, as then designed, were in compliance with the applicable requirements of the
Internal Revenue Code (IRC). The Plan has been amended since receiving the determination letter. However, Plan
management believes that the Plan is currently designed and being operated in compliance with the applicable
requirements of the IRC.
US GAAP requires Plan management to evaluate tax positions taken by the Plan and recognize a tax liability if the
Plan has taken an uncertain position that more likely than not would not be sustained upon examination by the IRS.
The Plan is subject to routine audits by taxing jurisdictions; however, there are currently no audits for any tax periods
in progress.
Note 9. Related Party and Party-in-Interest Transactions
Certain Master Trust investments are shares of common collective trusts managed by Northern Trust Company, the
Trustee for the Plan. Gallagher Benefit Services, Inc., provides actuarial and related services for the Plan. As described
in Note 2, the Plan paid certain expenses related to plan operations and investment activity to various services
providers. These transactions are party-in-interest transactions under ERISA.

in the Master Trust, as well as receivables.

Net assets transferred into the Plan include the Plan’s interest in the Master Trust, less any accrued expenses. The
transfers are not reflected in the accumulated plan benefits discussed in Note 4 as of January 1, 2024.
Note 11. Plan Amendments
Effective December 31, 2023, the Plan was amended to reflect the merger with the Aerojet Rocketdyne (GenCorp)
Consolidated Pension Plan. Under this amendment, the terms of each of the merging plans, as in effect immediately
prior to the merger, shall continue to be in effect at and after the Plan merger.
Effective December 31, 2024, the Plan was amended to reflect the mergers with the L3Harris Combat Propulsion
Systems Pension Plan, the Cooperative Pension Income Plan, the L3Harris Ocean Systems Pension Plan For Hourly
Employees, and the L3Harris Pension Plan for Employees at the Pacific Missile Range Facility. Under this amendment,
the terms of each of the merging plans, as in effect immediately prior to the merger, shall continue to be in effect
at and after the Plan mergers. The effect of this amendment is not reflected in the accumulated plan benefits
discussed in Note 4 as of January 1, 2024.
Note 12. Purchase of Annuity Contracts
On September 18, 2024, the Plan purchased two group annuity contracts from Nationwide Life and Annuity
Insurance Company (NLAIC) for $332,949. In 2025, the purchase price was amended to $320,403, which is
included in the statements of changes in net assets available for benefits. This amendment resulted in the
recognition of a $12,546 receivable, which is recognized in the statements of net assets available for benefits as of
December 31, 2024. Under the terms of the contracts, NLAIC is responsible for the annuity payments of those
annuitants identified in the contract effective as of December 1, 2024.
Note 13. Subsequent Events
The Plan has evaluated subsequent events through October 10, 2025, the date the financial statements were
available to be issued.
During March 2025, the Plan purchased two group annuity contracts from the Pacific Life Insurance Company
for $1,179,671. There were no adjustments to the Plan’s 2024 financial statements or benefit obligation resulting
from this transaction.

L3Harris Technologies Consolidated Pension Plan
EIN/PN: 34-0276860 / 023
Schedule SB, Part V – Summary of Plan Provisions (continued)
Section I: Salaried Retirement Plan (SRP)
Effective Date
January 1, 1976
Eligibility for Membership
All salaried employees age 21 with one year of service. The plan has been closed to new participants effective
October 1, 2011.
Normal Retirement Allowance
Eligibility
Age 65.
Benefit
For the first 40 years of benefit service, a participant may elect either of the following benefit accruals:
1) Traditional Pension Formula
2% of final average salary (1.5% for employees who became participants after January 1, 2000) during
the 5 years of service in the last 10 years giving the highest average, for each of the first 25 years of
traditional formula service, plus 1.5% of such final average salary for traditional formula service between
25 and 40 years, reduced by 1.25% of the Social Security benefit multiplied by traditional formula service
up to 40 years. An amendment effective January 1, 2012 provided employees a choice to accrue future
benefits under (1) the Traditional Pension Formula, or (2) an age-based defined contribution plan.
Effective December 31, 2016, accruals under the Traditional Pension formula ceased.
2) Pension Equity (PEP) Formula
Lump sum benefit based on the following percentages of final average salary: under age 30, 3% per year
of service, age 30 - age 39, 4% per year of service, age 40 - age 49, 5% per year of service, age 50 and
over, 6% per year of service. Total years credited cannot exceed 40. Effective January 1, 2012 (October
31, 2011 for ITT/Xylem employees), accrued percentage of final average salary and final average salary
were frozen. Also, effective January 1, 2012, the pension equity formula accruals option was no longer
available and the rate of interest to be credited towards the lump sum benefit for Harris employees shall
be the 10-year Treasury rate as in effect on December 31 of the prior calendar year but not less than
3.25%.
3) Cash Balance Formula
Effective January 1, 2017, a Cash Balance formula was added for certain eligible employees who were
non-highly compensated employees on December 31, 2016. Participants accumulate a Cash Balance
Account equal to 1% of each year’s compensation plus interest credited monthly based on the 30-year
Treasury rate as in effect for the month of November of the prior calendar year.
Special Early Retirement Allowance
Eligibility
For employees who became participants before January 1, 2000, age 55 and 15 years of service or age 50
with age and service totaling 80 or more years. For employees who became participants after December 31,
1999 but before January 1, 2005, age 55 and 15 years of service.

Benefit
For pre-January 1, 2000 participants; accrued pension under the traditional formula can commence as early

than 75% of the unreduced benefit that would have been payable at age 60. For post-December 31, 1999
participants; accrued pension under the traditional formula can commence as early as age 55 and is reduced

age 62. Accrued pension under PEP and Cash Balance formulas shall be payable in the form of a single lump
sum equal to the Account Balances or an actuarially equivalent annuity.
Standard Early Retirement Allowance
Eligibility
Age 55 and 10 years of service.
Benefit
Accrued pension under the traditional formula deferred to age 65 or an immediate benefit reduced 1/4 of 1%
for each month that payments commence prior to age 65. (For post- December 31, 2004 participants, the
reduction is 6.67% per annum for retirements between ages 60 to 65, and further reduced 3.33% per annum
for retirements before age 60.) Social Security reduction is not applied before age 62 for pre-January 1, 2005
participants. Accrued pension under PEP and Cash Balance formulas shall be payable in the form of a single
lump sum equal to the Account Balances or an actuarially equivalent annuity.
Vested Benefit
Eligibility
3 years of service.
Benefit

an actuarially equivalent annuity.
Vested Spouse Benefit
Eligibility
Death after becoming eligible for a vested benefit and prior to Benefit Commencement. Benefit commences
no earlier than earliest retirement date which could have been elected by deceased participant.
Benefit
Traditional Pension Formula - Accrued pension under traditional formula at time of death, adjusted as if
participant had retired on date payments to spouse commence under joint and 50% survivorship option, and
then died. For a terminated vested participant there is a charge for each year coverage is in effect after
termination date up to age 65. Coverage for which a charge is made may be waived with consent of the
spouse.
PEP and Cash Balance Formulas - Accrued pension under PEP and Cash Balance formulas payable to the
spouse in the form of actuarially equivalent annuity over the spouse’s lifetime or as a lump sum equal to the
Account Balances.

Eligibility

A Cash Accumulation Allocation of 1% of compensation will be credited for each plan year from January
1, 2001 through December 31, 2002. On the last day of each plan year, interest will be credited on the
Cash Accumulation Balance in effect as of the first day of the plan year. The interest crediting rate is
based on the annual 30-year Treasury rate in effect for the November prior to the start of the plan year.
Additional Prior Plan Benefit for employees hired on or before December 31, 2000:
For service from January 1, 2001 through December 31, 2002:
The product of (A) 1.0% of the Final Average Compensation of such Participant that is equal to or less
than one-half of the Taxable Wage Base, multiplied by (B) such Participant’s Credited Service from
January 1, 2001 through December 31, 2002; and

The greater of the five complete calendar years that produce the highest total compensation, divided by 60, or the
monthly average of compensation for the 60 consecutive highest paid calendar months out of the last 120
calendar months. Compensation is defined as base pay, plus variable pay, lump sum wage increases, shift
differential, overtime, commissions or sales payments, performance awards paid through payroll, and short-term
incentive compensation. No additional accrual service will be earned after December 31, 2018 but accruals due to
pay increases will apply.

Security benefit for the first 25 years of Credited Service, and 0.75% of final average compensation plus $8,
for the first 30 years of Credited Service. Special provisions for former participants in the Budd Company
Pension Plan: The greater of the frozen benefit under the Budd Company Pension Plan determined as of
March 31, 1995, and the retirement benefit accrued under this plan including service earned under the Budd
Company Pension Plan as of April 1, 1995.

Account and 50% Survivor Annuity of Employer paid benefit, without COLA. Payments commence on the
first day of the month following death or, if later, the earliest date on which the employee would have been

COLA.

Survivor Annuity of Employer paid benefit, without COLA.

receive a benefit commencing on the first day of the month following the date the participant would have
attained the earliest retirement age under the plan calculated as though the participant had elected to receive
benefits starting at such age, had elected the 50% joint and survivor option, and had died.
Actuarial Equivalence
For purposes of converting a Straight Life Annuity to an optional form of benefit, actuarial equivalence is based on
1971 Group Annuity Mortality Table, projected to 1980 by scale E, with male rates set back one year (unisex) and
a 7½ percent interest assumption.

(1) Life annuity
(2) Reduced Joint and 50% survivor annuity
(3) Reduced Joint and 75% survivor annuity
(4) Reduced Joint and 100% survivor annuity
(5) Life annuity with certain period of 10 years
(6) Social Security level income annuity
(7) Lump sum; Benefits with present value less than or equal to $1,000 are automatically cashed out. If the
present value of the benefit is greater than $1,000 but less than or equal to $5,000, a lump sum is offered to

Actuarial Equivalence
Joint and 50% survivor annuity: 0.90 + 0.005 * (y – x) but not > 0.999
Joint and 75% survivor annuity: 0.85 + 0.0075 * (y – x) but not > 0.999
Joint and 100% survivor annuity: 0.80 + 0.01 * (y – x) but not > 0.999
Where “x” is the participant’s age at retirement and “y” is the beneficiary’s age at retirement.
All other forms: UP 1984 Table with the PBGC interest rate that is in effect for the period commencing two months
prior to the actual retirement date.

Credited Service
Years and full months of service as a covered employee.
Vesting Service
Years and partial months of service as a covered employee.
Annual Plan Compensation
The compensation used for determining pension plan benefits. Generally, it includes wages, salary, overtime pay,
year-end payments or bonuses, vacation and sick pay, shift differentials, and amounts deferred under Code
Section 401(k), Code Section 125, and the Deferred Bonus Plan of Aerojet Rocketdyne Holdings, Inc. and

Final Average Earnings
Effective October 1, 1999, Final Average Earnings is the highest average monthly Plan Compensation determined
over any 60 consecutive month period beginning 60 calendar months prior to October 1, 1999 and ending prior to

Affiliated Company prior to October 1, 1999, the Final Average Earnings is the highest average compensation
over 5 continuous Plan Years (5-year average).
Average Social Security Wage Base (ASSWB)
For benefit calculations under this Program, the Average Social Security Wage Base (ASSWB) for any Plan Year
is the 35-year average of the Social Security Taxable Wage Bases ending with the calendar year containing the
beginning of the Plan Year. The ASSWB is determined as of the earlier of (1) your last day worked under
Program B or (2) the Freeze Date.

Plan Status
Closed group of inactive participants.
Covered Employees
All salaried employees of Aerojet Fine Chemicals, excluding Aerojet employees covered under Aerojet

Participation Date
First day of the month coinciding with or next following date of hire.
Credited Service
One year of Credited Service is provided for each 2,080-hours of employment in a Plan Year, with pro-rate credit
of one month for each 173 hours of service. No Credited Service is provided after the termination of employment.
Vesting Service
One year of Vesting Service is provided for each 1,000-hours of employment in a Plan Year, with pro-rata credit
of one month for each 173 hours of service.
Annual Earnings
The compensation paid during the Plan Year used for determining pension plan benefits. Generally, it includes
wages, salary, overtime pay, year-end payments or bonuses, vacation and sick pay, shift differentials, and
amounts deferred under Code Section 401(k), Code Section 125, and the Deferred Bonus Plan of Aerojet
Rocketdyne Holdings, Inc. and Participating Subsidiaries.
Final Average Earnings
The highest average of any five consecutive plan years of Annual Earnings preceding the date of retirement or
termination.
Average Social Security Wage Base (ASSWB)
The 35-year average of the Social Security Taxable Wage Bases ending with the calendar year containing the
beginning of the Plan Year. The ASSWB is determined as of the last day worked.

Monthly Pension Benefit
One-twelfth of the highest benefit under A, B, C, or D, offset by E below.
A. The sum of a, b, c and d
a. The accrued benefit at November 30, 1984; plus
b. A frozen amount for the period November 30, 1984 through December 1, 1985; plus
c. For Credited Service between November 30, 1985 and November 30, 1989, 1.2% of Annual
Earnings up to $15,000, plus 2% of Annual Earnings in excess of $15,000; plus
d. For Credited Service after November 30, 1989, 1.625% of Annual Earnings up to the ASSWB, plus
2% of Annual Earnings in excess of the ASSWB until 35 years of total Credited Service are
completed, plus 2% of Annual Earnings for the Credited Service after 35 years.
B. $44 per year of Credited Service.
C. 1.125% of Final Average Earnings up to the ASSWB plus 1.5% of Final Average Earnings in excess of the
ASSWB, times years of Credited Service up to 35 years; plus 1.5% of Final Average Earnings times the
years of Credited Service after 35 years.
D. For credited service prior to December 1, 1989, 1.2% of Annual Earnings up to $15,000, plus 2% of Annual
Earnings in excess of $15,000; plus the annual benefits determined under A.d. above, for periods on or
after December 1, 1989.
E. The monthly benefit accrued under the Aerojet-General Corporation Consolidated Pension Plan for salaried
employees (Program F) at the date of transfer to the AFC plan prior to June 1, 2000.

Eligibility
First of month coinciding with or next following the attainment of age 65.

Monthly Pension Benefit determined as of normal retirement date.

The amount of the disability pension benefit will be based on years of Credited Service prior to the
participant’s total and permanent disability, plus years of Credited Service up to the earlier of (1) the freeze
date or (2) the date the participant’s total and permanent disability ends. To determine the participant’s
pension rate of accrual during the total and permanent disability period the participant’s base monthly salary
will be used. Base monthly salary is the monthly salary (i.e., not including bonuses, commissions, overtime, or
other pay) in effect at the earlier of 1) the participant’s last day worked, or 2) the freeze date.
Pre-Retirement Death Benefit
Eligibility
5 years of service.
Benefit
Unless otherwise preselected, spouse will receive 50% of amount the participant would have received if
he/she had survived and elected to commence payment at the earliest date allowed, payable under the
qualified 50% joint and survivor annuity.

Schedule SB, Part V – Summary of Plan Provisions (continued)
Section XXII: Aerojet East - Program G
Plan Status
Benefit accruals were frozen effective February 1, 2009.
Covered Employees
All employees hired on or after October 17, 2003 at former Atlantic Research Corporation locations or who were
part of the Transfer Group. The Transfer Group is defined as those employees hired by Aerojet-General
Corporation pursuant to the purchase agreement related to the acquisition of Atlantic Research Corporation
(“ARC”) on October 17, 2003 as Employees.
Participation Date
Effective October 17, 2003, or date of hire, if later.
Credited Service
Years and months of service as a covered employee prior to February 1, 2009, including the service with ARC, its
subsidiaries, or with an entity acquired by ARC, or an affiliate, if hired as part of the Transfer Group. A full month
of service is credited for each month in which at least one hour of service is worked.
Vesting Service
Years and months of service as a covered employee, including the service with ARC, its subsidiaries, or with an
entity acquired by ARC, or an affiliate, if hired as part of the transfer group. A full month of service is credited for
each month in which at least one hour of service is worked.
Annual Earnings
Base wages, overtime payments, and shift differentials excluding bonuses. Annual Earnings on or after the
Freeze Date is excluded.
Final Average Earnings
Annual Earnings averaged for the five consecutive plan years during which the participant’s Annual Earnings
were the highest during the ten-year period immediately preceding the earlier of (1) the participant’s date of
termination with the company, or (2) the freeze date. Final Average Earnings is the average Annual Earnings over
the period of Credited Service if there are less than five consecutive plan years of employment.
Covered Compensation
Covered Compensation is based on the year the participant attains Social Security Retirement Age (SSRA). It is
the average of the Social Security Taxable Wage Bases over a 35-year period that ends the plan year ending in
the calendar year the participant attains SSRA.
Covered Compensation is determined as of the earlier of (1) the participant’s last day worked or (2) the freeze
date.

L3Harris Technologies Consolidated Pension Plan
EIN/PN: 34-0276860 / 023
Schedule SB, Part V – Summary of Plan Provisions (continued)
Section XXII: Aerojet East - Program G (continued)
Monthly Pension Benefit
Projected benefit based on the Credited Service at normal retirement date is equal to one-twelfth of the sum of:
a. 0.95% of Final Average Earnings, times years of projected Credited Service up to 25 years; plus
b. 0.65% of the excess of Final Average Earnings over covered compensation, times years of projected
Credited Service up to 25 years; plus
c. 0.40% of Final Average Earnings, times years of projected Credited Service over 25 years; minus
d. The benefit at normal retirement date (if any) under the “ARC” plan.
The monthly pension benefit at benefit commencement date is the sum of items a through d, multiplied by the
ratio of actual Credited Service at the earlier of (1) the date of termination or (2) the freeze date, to projected
Credited Service at age 65.
ARC Offset
The ARC Retirement Benefit Offset is an offset of the monthly pension benefit at normal retirement date for those
participants who were part of the Transfer Group. In calculating the monthly pension benefit at normal retirement
date, a participant’s ARC prior service and pay are used for vesting and calculating final average compensation.
The monthly pension benefit at normal retirement date is determined using ARC pay and service history, plus
additional pay and service earned under the plan, up to earlier of (1) the date of termination, (2) normal retirement
date, or (3) the freeze date. The monthly pension benefit at normal retirement date under the plan will be offset by
the value of the participant’s monthly pension benefit at normal retirement date under the Atlantic Research
Corporation Employee Pension Plan.
Normal Retirement Pension
Eligibility
First of month coinciding with or next following the attainment of age 65.
Benefit
Monthly Pension Benefit determined as of normal retirement date.

The monthly life annuity payable at retirement adjusted to reflect accruals with the UTC Plan up to June 30, 2013.

Schedule SB, Part V – Statement of Actuarial Assumptions/Methods
Funding assumptions selection and rationale
Actuarial Standard of Practice No. 27 (“ASOP 27”) provides guidance to actuaries on economic assumptions for
measuring pension obligations. Actuarial Standard of Practice No. 35 (“ASOP 35”) provides guidance to actuaries
on demographic and other noneconomic assumptions for measuring pension obligations. Under these ASOPs, for
each assumption that has a significant effect on the measurement and that the actuary has selected, the actuary
should disclose the information and analysis used to support the actuary’s determination that, in the actuary's
professional judgement, it is reasonable for the purpose of the measurement. No information or analysis is
needed for any assumption prescribed by law or regulation.
The interest rates and mortality assumption used for this measurement are prescribed by law.
The economic assumption that has a significant effect on the measurement and that the actuary has selected is
the expected rate of return on plan assets. The expected rate of return on plan assets assumption was based on
an analysis of long term expected returns for the asset classes in which the plan’s assets were invested as of the
measurement date. Demographic and other non-economic assumptions having a significant impact on the
measurement of the Funding Target are retirement rates, withdrawal rates, and the frequency of optional forms of
payment. For all the legacy L3 pension subplans and the Aerojet subplan, the retirement rates, withdrawal rates,
and the frequency of optional forms of payment were set to the assumptions used by the prior actuary. These
assumptions are based on the plan sponsor’s anticipated experience. Actual experience for prior year was
reviewed and compared to the assumption. Changes are made, as appropriate, based on the review.
Use of Models
Actuarial Standard of Practice No. 56 (“ASOP 56”) provides guidance to actuaries when performing actuarial
services that involve designing, developing, selecting, modifying, using, reviewing, or evaluating models.
Gallagher used third-party software to perform the calculations that underlie the actuarial information contained in
this report. The model in the third-party software calculated the actuarial information provided in this report using
plan provisions, data, and assumptions as of a measurement date under rules applicable to the calculations.
Gallagher has an extensive review process whereby the results of the calculations are checked using detailed
sample output, changes from year to year are summarized by source, and significant deviations from
expectations are investigated. Other outputs are similarly reviewed in detail and at a high level for accuracy,
reasonability, and consistency with prior results. Gallagher also reviews the model when software changes occur.
The review is performed by experts who are familiar with applicable rules and the way the model generates its
output.
Future actuarial measurements
Future actuarial measurements may differ significantly from current measurements due to plan experience
differing from that anticipated by the actuarial assumptions, changes expected as part of the natural operation of
the methodology used for these measurements, and changes in plan provisions, applicable law or regulations. An
analysis of the potential range of such future differences is beyond the scope of this report. However, in
accordance with ASOP 51, an assessment of risks for the plan was performed.

Actuarial cost method
The Funding Target is the present value of accrued benefits based on compensation and service to date. The
Target Normal Cost is the present value of benefits expected to be accrued during the current plan year, reflecting
the effect of expected compensation increases during the year and including plan related expenses expected to
be paid from plan assets during the year.

Asset valuation method
The Actuarial Value of Assets is market value as of the valuation date, including the discounted value of accrued
contributions, reduced by 2/3 of the gain/(loss) for the immediately preceding plan year and reduced by 1/3 of the
gain/(loss) for the plan year before that. The gain/(loss) for each period is determined as the actual return on
market value during the period less the expected return on market value based on an assumed earnings rate
chosen by the actuary but required by current law and regulation to be not greater than the applicable third
Segment Rate. The resulting value is constrained to be within a corridor of 90% to 110% of market value,
including discounted receivable contributions.

Schedule SB, Part V – Statement of Actuarial Assumptions/Methods (continued)
Funding Assumptions and Methods – All Groups
Summary of Changes from the January 1, 2023 Valuation
 The interest rate basis was updated to the current rates as specified in IRS Regulation 1.430(h)(2)-1. These
rates are constrained in accordance with relevant legislation.
 The mortality assumption was updated according to the projection as specified in IRS Regulation 1.430(h)(3)-
1, as amended in the Federal Register on October 20, 2023, in TD 9983, 88 FR 72357, applied on a fully
generational basis using the IRS 2024 Adjusted Scale MP-2021 Rates mortality improvement scale.
 The mortality used for computing lump sums was updated to the 2024 IRS 417(e)(3) Applicable Mortality
table, as amended by IRS Notice 2023-73 for the applicable subplans.
 Cash Balance Interest Accumulation Rate was changed from 4.00% to 4.50% for the applicable subplans.
This was updated to reflect expected cash balance interest crediting rates due to the recent increase in the
treasury bills.
 The employee contribution accumulation rate assumption was changed from 3.75% to 4.25% for the
applicable subplans. This was updated to reflect expected interest crediting rates due to the recent increase
in the treasury bills.
 The impact of the above changes increased the Funding Target.

of Revenue Procedure 2017-56.
